problem.question: What is output by the code to the right?
problem.code:
String colors = "REDBLUE";
Stack<Character> st;
st = new Stack<>();

for(int i = 0; i < colors.length(); i++)
  st.push( colors.charAt(i) );

while( !st.isEmpty() )
  System.out.print(st.pop());

problem.question:
What is output by the code
to the right?
problem.code:
// IntStack implements the traditional
// stack operations for ints
IntStack s = new IntStack();

for(int i = 0; i < 10; i += 2)
  s.push(i);

while( !s.isEmpty() )
  System.out.print( s.pop() );

problem.question:
Which of the following correctly
replaces <*1> in the code to 
the right?
problem.code:
Stack<Integer> x = <*1>;
x.push(22);
x.push(42);
x.push(84);
out.print(x.peek()+x.peek()); //2
x.push(12);
x.push(14);
x.pop();
x.pop();
out.println(x.pop() + x.peek() + x.size()); //3

problem.question:
What is output by line
marked //2 in the code
to the right?
problem.code:
Stack<Integer> x = <*1>;
x.push(22);
x.push(42);
x.push(84);
out.print(x.peek()+x.peek()); //2
x.push(12);
x.push(14);
x.pop();
x.pop();
out.println(x.pop() + x.peek() + x.size()); //3

problem.question:
What is output by line 
marked //3 in the code
to the right?
problem.code:
Stack<Integer> x = <*1>;
x.push(22);
x.push(42);
x.push(84);
out.print(x.peek()+x.peek()); //2
x.push(12);
x.push(14);
x.pop();
x.pop();
out.println(x.pop() + x.peek() + x.size()); //3

problem.question:
What is output by the code
to the right?
problem.code:
Stack<Integer> s;
s = new Stack<>();

for(int i = 5; i >= 0; i--)
  s.push(i);

while(s.size()>1)
{
  int sum = s.pop() + s.pop();

  if( sum % 3 == 1)
    continue;

  s.push( sum );
}
System.out.println(s.pop());

problem.question:
What replaces <*1> in the code to
the right to tell whether data
member elements is empty?
problem.code:
public class Stack {

  private ArrayList<E> elements;

  public Stack() {
    elements = new ArrayList<>();
  }

  public void push(E element) {
    elements.add(element);
  }

  public E pop() {
    return elements.remove(
    elements.size()-1);
  }

  public boolean isEmpty() {
    return <*1>;
  }

  public static void test() {
    <*2>
    s.push(15);
    s.push(17);
    s.push(35);
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
  }

}

problem.question:
Which of these replaces <*2> in
the code to the right as a valid
declaration and initialization 
of a stack of integer values?
problem.code:
public class Stack {

  private ArrayList<E> elements;

  public Stack() {
    elements = new ArrayList<>();
  }

  public void push(E element) {
    elements.add(element);
  }

  public E pop() {
    return elements.remove(
    elements.size()-1);
  }

  public boolean isEmpty() {
    return <*1>;
  }

  public static void test() {
    <*2>
    s.push(15);
    s.push(17);
    s.push(35);
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
  }

}

problem.question:
Assume <*1> and <*2> are filled 
in correctly.What is output by
the test() static method?
problem.code:
public class Stack<E> {

  private ArrayList<E> elements;

  public Stack() {
    elements = new ArrayList<>();
  }

  public void push(E element) {
    elements.add(element);
  }

  public E pop() {
    return elements.remove(
    elements.size()-1);
  }

  public boolean isEmpty() {
    return <*1>;
  }

  public static void test() {
    <*2>
    s.push(15);
    s.push(17);
    s.push(35);
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
    System.out.print(s.pop());
  }

}
